ILITIES OVERVIEW

The purpose of the DGA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program is to prevent unwanted releases or spills of hazardous chemicals, specifically Anhydrous Ammonia, and Hydrochloric Acid into locations which could expose our employees or our community to serious hazards. In addition, it is required to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management Regulation.

Our process safety management program requires a systematic whole process approach to release prevention. It includes a properly designed system, well defined maintenance and operating procedures, adequately trained employees, emergency and/or release mitigation backup systems in place.

OSHA'S Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation final rule issued February 24, 1992 with an effective date of May 26, 1992.  It includes a compliance with same provisions and was extended from May 26, 1992 until August 26, 1992.

The regulation is the outgrowth of a need perceived by OSHA for regulatory provisions to minimize or eliminate catastrophic major incidents in industries processing and handling Highly Hazardous Chemicals. The regulation builds on recommended process safety practices developed by the American Petroleum Institute and the American Institute of Chemical Engineers. It also considers input from numerous operating companies, trade associations and professional organizations.

RESPONSIBILITIES

The plant manager is responsible for implementing the Process Safety Management Regulations, at the Texas City Plant. He will respond and submit all required documentation and reports in accordance with OSHA 11910.119.

1.	GOALS AND BENEFITS OF PSM AND PSM DOCUMENTATION

The first goal of PSM is to take appropriate steps at the right time to prevent incidents to protect life, property, and the environment. Preventive maintenance programs, training programs, and Management of Change (MOC) have all been developed to help achieve this goal. PHA is conducted not only in the project phase of

the facility life cycle, but also in the operating phase to identify and address potential causes of incidents. When incidents do occur, investigations are conducted, corrective actions are proposed, and modifications are made to prevent further occurrences. The likelihood of success of these and other PSM, efforts is enhanced by, or in some cases is dependent upon, accurate, effective documentation.
 
It may not be possible to prevent every incident. Thus, the second goal of PSM is to minimize the hazardous consequences of incidents that do occur. For example, during a process upset, the pressure in a reactor may exceed the design pressure; therefore, relief systems are provided to restrict the pressure to a safe level by discharging a portion of the reactor's contents. However, the hazardous discharge must be directed safely to prevent serious injury or damage resulting from the operation of the protective device. The objectives of each of these stages of protection is documented via design drawings, operating procedures, maintenance procedures and training requirements. This documentation enables the many people who may be involved with the reactor system (e.g., operations, maintenance, process control, or engineering personnel) to be more fully aware of the operational requirements of the equipment and of their responsibilities. This reduces the likelihood that the protections are compromised during the operating life of the facility.

The third goal of PSM is to enhance compliance with industry initiatives such as the Chemical Manufacturers Association (CMA) Responsible Care program or the American Petroleum Institute (API) Recommended Practice (RP) 750, and to satisfy regulatory requirements. Adequate documentation of procedures and audit results enhances the confidence of the public, and of regulatory bodies, that industry is being a good corporate citizen.
